title: Great app to use during the bushfires
review: This app has been invaluable in helping to cope with bushfire smoke in Australia. It’s helped me plan my life around local air quality, so that I know e.g. when I need to wear a mask, or when I can go for a run. It’s definitely helped prevent/alleviate the symptoms from smoke/particulate inhalation that I was experiencing before I started using it.

title: Really useful information
review:
We have an ‘eco’ woodburner and as an asthmatic I have noticed that I am symptomatic on the days it is lit. We love the stove and use it a lot in the evenings. 
It burns very cleanly so I was wondering if particulates are escaping when the door is opened to add wood.
The monitor showed that the problem is just when the kindling is lit and the door has to be left slightly ajar. As soon as the stove reaches temperature there are no more peaks to purple even with the door opened.
I now wear a mask when lighting the stove until the air quality improves ( 5-10 mins with ventilation) and am considering buying an IQ air purifier. 
Other helpful info was a rise to red when cooking on the hob including an increased humidity reading in the house. This was rectified by cleaning the extractor hood filters.
The high C02 readings when all the family was in one room has led us to ventilate the house more and this really improves air quality as seen by the green readings.

All in all a very useful purchase-easy to set up and use and great for anyone with allergies to see what may be triggering symptoms. 
Highly recommended.

title: A tragic reality
review:
Amazingly helpful app, both for health and as a driver of environmental action. Awful to see the country I live in has removed the app from its domestic app stores while leading a campaign to discredit the horrific readings it relays simply because polluting the air is how companies (and governments) make short-term profits.

It seems we have entered an age of anti science, where the most ignorant minds feel legitimized in overlooking the work and the warnings of the most intelligent, simply because what they’re seeing and reading doesn’t match their own blinkered agenda.

Download this app, tell your friends to download this app, share the information and never lose sight of how bad the situation really is. If not for you, do it for your kids.

title: Excellent air quality app
review:
I used this whilst traveling when I noticed I was struggling with a sore throat and itchy eyes whenever I went outside (it wasn't hayfever season); I was shocked to see how poor the air quality was in the location I was visiting and it allowed me to avoid going outside when the quality was at its worst.

Since returning to the UK I still use it to monitor air auality and whilst most the time it's green, it's good to get alerts when things get worse.

It's very localised and you have the option to add your own air quality unit to your house, then share the data with the app.

Really nicely done app. Recommended for the curious or those who suffer when air quality is poor.

title: Air quality app
review: I was introduced to this app via a friend who lives in London and I live in Highlands of Scotland . I wanted to compare the air quality and see IF there differences . I began to question the numbers as on occasion they were the slightly the same . How can that meaning maki g be possible? As the geography is different , the demographics is different, the car volume is different etc, So I am curious about this app . It is helping me remain curious about the stats

title: Quite a lot of PM2.5 sensors
review:
About dozen points measuring PM2.5 around Chiang Mai, Thailand.
Very useful info, especially during haze/burning season where the values skyrocket...
I have tested many other apps, none has such friendly UI and abundance of data.
I wish is that AirVisual would include PM10 sensors, so I could just use 1 app (getting PM10 info from AirMatters).
The bubbly notifier (the number on app icon) need to be force updated, so it is great idea, but kinda pointless, as I have to open the app anyway to update it.

Overall, the app is not ideal, still gets 5 stars as the best in AppStore. Hopefully the development will continue and make competition irrelevant.
Good job!

title: Informative and reliable
review: Really like the app. It is easy to use and regularly updates so you can be assured of the information given.

title: Great App...Will Give 5* With More Local Stations
review: Needs more local locations, then will be a 5* App...Very useful

title: Seems to do exactly what it says on the tin
review: I've no idea how accurate it is, but it seems to be getting the data from legitimate sources. Gives you a reasonable heads up when to watch out for smog in places like Shanghai. Which is useful for me.

title: Good app, bad notifications
review: App is good with reliable info, but it'll overload you with notifications. A day can equate to 99 red notifications which is actually pretty annoying. No clear sign on how to disable that yet...

title: Useful
review: A great app with clear and clean icons, making it an app I can use at a glance. In Korea, it doesn't seem to sync up with some of the local reports accurately; showing warnings when there otherwise shouldn't be. A good improvement would be for clear alerts. Also, a watch app would be killer! Great work though overall.

title: Good apps
review: Perfect!

title: Good
review: A good app which I am sure does a lot more if I had instruction.

title: Keep us educated.
review: Great App. Showing number. Of healthy or in healthy all over the world.

title: Fair
review: It’s good but it doesn’t have some country’s like North Korea

title: Great phone app but watch complication crashes
review:
5 stars for the ihone app which is proving invaluable as Bangkok suffers heavy smog.

Despite an update today the watch complication crashes the watch app on my phone, or my watch itself everytime I try to add it to an infograph on either device.
dev_response:
Hi Ian&Chris,
We are sorry you are experiencing troubles with the Apple Watch.
Please contact us via this link so our team can help: https://www.airvisual.com/contact 
The AirVisual team

title: Great info and interface
review: But crashes all the time

title: Useful but some glitches
review: See title

title: Poorly
review: It isn’t online if reads 12 times a day.

title: User experience?
review: How can you fail to make deleting a weather station straightforward?

title: Widget not working.
review: The widget does not work, no matter what different settings I try. Just says no data is available.

title: Accuracy concern
review: I have high concern about accuracy of the measurement of the app. It announce that it has a sensor in US Embassy, but this announcement is highly doubted.

title: App language problem
review: I speak English but live in Taiwan. The AirVisual app is set to Chinese and doesn’t let me change the language. If it was fixed to device language that would be fine.
